children.value: Tairo is a dashboard system built by
Tairo is a premium template sold on
. You have to purchase a license to get access to the source.
Once you own a license, you will be able to download the source from your ThemeForest account. You can also get your
from us, which will allow you to get the latest updates, before they're even released on ThemeForest.

props.title: Get help from our support team

children.value: When purchasing a license, you get access to our
up to six months after your order. You can ask questions, send your feedback, report bugs and get help from our support team.
before asking for help, as it may help you solve your issue faster.
Once your support period is over, we still give you the opportunity to ask questions on our support portal, but we cannot guarantee a response.
In any case, we encourage you to join us on our
, where you can find previous answers to common questions and get help from the community. Feel free to share your feedback, ideas and promote your projects!
to get help from the community.
We do not recommend using the latest version of Node.js as they might introduce breaking changes and produce unexpected results with underlying dependencies.

props.code:
node -v
# v18.x.x

children.value: For windows users, we recommend using
. We use pnpm because it is fast and disk space efficient. It also has a great support for workspaces.

Workspaces is a feature of pnpm that allows you to manage multiple packages in a single repository (similar to Lerna). We use workspaces to manage the different layers of the template. Each layer is a package that has its own dependencies. Some of them can be disabled to reduce the final and dev bundle sizes.

props.code: corepack prepare pnpm@latest --activate

children.value: Then you can check that pnpm is installed and activated.

props.code:
pnpm -v
# 8.x.x

children.value: If you downloaded the source from ThemeForest, you normally have a zip file containing the template. You need to extract the zip file and open a terminal in the extracted folder.
When using the private github repository, you simply need to clone it on your machine and open a terminal in the cloned folder.
In both cases, you should have the same file and folder structure as this:

props.code:
├── .app # This is the entry point of your app (main app layer)
├── .demo # This is the entry point of the demo (demo app layer)
├── .vscode # Predefined vscode settings
├── layers # Each layer is a package with its own dependencies
│   ├── documentation
│   ├── landing
│   ├── tairo
│   ├── tairo-layout-collapse
│   └── tairo-layout-sidebar
│   └── tairo-layout-topnav
├── types # Extra typescript definitions
├── # Predefined dotfiles
├── .editorconfig
├── .eslintignore
├── .eslintrc.cjs
├── .gitignore
├── .npmrc
├── .nuxtrc
├── .prettierignore
├── .prettierrc
├── # Monorepo configuration files
├── package.json
├── pnpm-lock.yaml
├── pnpm-workspace.yaml
└── tsconfig.json

Nuxt is a full-stack framework that combines Vue.js and Nitro to create universal applications.
With a few settings, you can swap from a full SSR application to a static application, or even a combination of both. Create full server applications as a replacement of
for instance, or create a full stack application with a single framework, including fully typed code, optimized payload, and more.
It also has out-of-the-box support for a high number of pre configured providers, including Edge Worker, such as
Read pages and layouts guide on nuxt.com
A Nuxt application can grow very fast. You can be multiple developers working on the same application, or you can have multiple applications that share common features.
Layers is a mechanism that allows you to split your application into multiple directories, each with their own
file. Each directory can be a full Nuxt application, with its own
At the end, all layers are merged together, representing a single application.

In order to keep your application maintainable, you need to organize your code. We help you do that with Nuxt Layers. The code in Tairo does not interfere with your own code, has minimal dependencies, and all features are optional, meaning they won't be loaded if you don't actually use them.
You can also override any component, by creating a component with the same name in your application. This allows you to customize Tairo to your needs, without having to rewrite all the code.
Learn more about Layers on nuxt.com
Tairo is a set of Nuxt layers that you can enable depending on your needs.
This creates a Nuxt application that contains only what's actually used. Keep only the layers you need, and remove the ones you don't, so that your application is as light as possible.
It also a great and efficient way for us to provide you with more features and updates, without taking the risk to break your application!

This layer provides base components for Tairo, such as buttons, inputs, and cards. It also loads Tailwind CSS, and provides a set of Tailwind CSS components that you can use to style your application.
This layer is required to use Tairo. It provides features for main content in Tairo, such as table components, the panel system, the toaster system, and more.
This layer provides a sidebar layout, with a sidebar and a content area. It also provides a sidebar menu component.
This layer provides a collapse layout, with a collapse menu and a content area. It also provides a collapse menu component.
This layer provides a top navigation layout, with a list of single links. It also provides two slots for the navbar header and toolbar.
This layer is the demo app. It is used to show you how you can use Tairo, with concrete examples.
This layer is an optional layer that you can enable to show the documentation. It uses
to load the documentation from the markdown files.
This layer contains everyting related to Tairo's landing page. It mainly to demonstrates that you can, and should, split your application into multiple layers.
This layer is your app. It is the layer that you will use to create your application with Tairo. See it as a Tairo starter app with the bare bones.
To enable a layer, you need to add it to the
In the example below, we load all the layers available in Tairo.
Sometime you may need to override components used in base layers. Instead of editing them directly, we recommend you to copy them in your
This way, you can still get updates from the base layers without losing your changes.
A good example is to override
Don't forget to place your logo files in the
Tairo needs you to install the dependencies defined in all
You can check which directories are considered as package in the
To do so, use the following command:

props.code: pnpm install

children.value: folder in each package containing the dependencies.
You may need to remove them if you update the dependencies, you can use

props.code: find . -maxdepth 4 -name node_modules -type d -prune -exec rm -rf {} \;

children.value: Now you can start the project using the following command:

props.code: pnpm dev

folder and open the frontend in your browser. You can now start editing the files and see the changes in real time.
Once you are done, you can stop the development server by pressing
on macOS) in your terminal. To deploy the project for production, use the
command. This will build the project in the
The base structure of the Tairo starter is an empty Nuxt app that only extends from the Tairo layer.
Here is the structure of the

props.code:
├── .app # This is the entry point of your app (main app layer)
│   ├── layouts
│   │   └── default.vue # use Tairo sidebar layout as default
│   ├── README.md
│   ├── app.config.ts # Your app configuration
│   ├── nuxt.config.ts # Your nuxt configuration (register layers)
│   ├── package.json # Your custom dependencies
│   ├── tailwind.config.ts # Your tailwind configuration
│   └── tsconfig.json
├── layers
│   └── tairo # Contains Tairo shared ready-to-use components
│   └── tairo-sidebar-layout # Contains Tairo sidebar layout

The source of the main demo is separated from the Tairo source,
allowing you to simply remove it if not needed, in order to start from a clean project.
The Tairo demo is split into differents layers:

props.code:
├── .demo # This is the entry point of the demo (demo app layer)
├── layers
│   ├── documentation # Contains nuxt/content related features
│   ├── landing # Contains marketing related features
│   ├── tairo # Contains Tairo shared ready-to-use components
│   └── tairo-sidebar-layout # Contains Tairo sidebar layout
│   └── tairo-collapse-layout # Contains Tairo collapse layout
│   └── tairo-topnav-layout # Contains Tairo topnav layout

The first time you run the Tairo project, you should see the Tairo Welcome page. To replace it, you need to create a

folder to see how to assemble your page. You will see that most pages are built with reusable components,
some are prefixed by
prefix is used for UI components (Shuriken UI components), sometimes known as atoms, like buttons, inputs, etc...
prefix is used for components that are specific to the project layouts, or reusable components that have no dependencies
prefix is used for components that are specific to the demo, like the quick search, widgets, etc...
prefix is for components that have external dependencies, like the markdown editor, charts, etc...
Use the quick search to find the component you need, try it now with
Learn about pages directory on nuxt.com

directory. These event handlers are automatically registered as API routes by Nitro.
route that will return a greeting message.

in your browser or by using

curl -i http://localhost:3000/api/hello?from=world

# content-type: text/html
# date: Wed, 19 Apr 2023 18:03:31 GMT
# connection: close
# content-length: 12
#

Layouts are used to define the structure of your page. Tairo has multiple layout options (two at the moment and more in the future), they mostly differ by how the navigation experience is handled.
layer, it's the default layout used on the demo app.
layer, it has better navigation experience when few items are needed to be displayed.
layer, it has better navigation experience when very few items are needed to be displayed.
To keep things simple, we grouped each layout in a dedicated nuxt layer, so they have their own set of components, composables, configuration and dependencies.

props.code:
├── .app
├── layers
│   └── tairo-layout-sidebar # register 'sidebar' layout
│   ├── tairo-layout-collapse # register 'collapse' layout
│   ├── tairo-layout-topnav # register 'topnav' layout

children.value:
├── .app
├── layers
│   └── tairo-layout-sidebar # register 'sidebar' layout
│   ├── tairo-layout-collapse # register 'collapse' layout
│   ├── tairo-layout-topnav # register 'topnav' layout
To enable a layout, you need to add it to the
To learn more about layers, check out the
folders of enabled layers) will be considered as pages. You can assign a layout to a page by adding the

props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
definePageMeta({
  // Layout can be set on a per page basis
  layout: 'sidebar',
})
</script>

children.value:
<script setup lang="ts">
definePageMeta({

Instead of setting the layout on each page, you can create a
component that will be used as the default layout for all pages. In this component, you just have to include the main component of the layout you want to use, in this case we use

props.code:
<template>
  <TairoSidebarLayout>
    <slot />
  </TairoSidebarLayout>
</template>

children.value: As layouts differ by how the navigation experience is handled, they also have their own set of configuration options. In order to have a great developer experience, we defined a dedicated schema for each layout so you can have autocompletion in your

This configuration depends on each layout, you'll be able to learn more about each one of these in the dedicated layout documentation, but here is a quick configuration example for the sidebar layout.
Find more information about how to setup navigation in the
You should still be able to optout from the default layout by setting the

props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
definePageMeta({
  // Don't use the default layout for this page
  layout: 'empty',
})
</script>

page, which has advanced layout configuration.

A Nuxt application is configured through the
file. In this file, we can setup core features of nuxt, enable modules, configure them, extend from other layers, and more.
file that is used to configure the layer itself. Layers can also have a
file that is used to manage the layer's default app configuration. In that case, you should also find a
file that is used to define the layer's configuration schema.
This is an overview of the nuxt configuration file. It's used to change the way nuxt works
(disable server-side rendering, change the build directory, etc, apply cache rules to specific routes, ...)
file is not exposed in either the client or the server. To expose a variable to the client, you need to use the
property. This property is used to expose variables to the client, and to the server.
The runtime config can then be accessed in the server using the
And in the client using same composable, note that you only have access to the

props.code:

const config = useRuntimeConfig()
// config.public.mapboxToken

property, you can use environment variables to define their value. This is useful when you want to use different values for different environments.

files to define environment variables. These files are located at the root of your project and are named

In addition to the nuxt configuration, another file is used to configure the app itself. This file is named
and is used to configure the app layout, theme, and more.
App configuration can then be accessed in components using the
nuxt composable. We use this internally to configure the layout, the theme, and other features, but nothing stops you from using it to configure your own components.

props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
const appConfig = useAppConfig()
// appConfig.tairo
</script>

The sidebar layout is a double sided navigation layout. It has a sidebar with a list of menu links and a subsidebar with a list of submenu links.

The icon sidebar is the first part of the double sided navigation of the sidebar layout. It displays the logo and the main navigation icon links. Those navigation items can be displayed as a link or a button that triggers an action.
The subsidebar works as a submenu element for each navigation item. It's a custom component that you have to create. We provide a set of components and prebuilt variations to help you to build it.
The toolbar is displayed at the top of the main content area. It can be used to display the current page title and a set of quick actions.
When scrolling down, the circular menu is displayed at the top right of the screen. It can be used to display a set of quick actions.
If you feel the sidebar has too many items for your app, you can use a smaller option that is the
First you need to enable the sidebar layout layer in the
Then you can configure the sidebar layout in the
You don't need to specify all the properties, only the ones you want to override.
to the toolbar or the circular menu, you have to create global components, and add them to the
The default configuration will display the logo in the sidebar as:

props.code: <TairoLogo class="text-primary-600 h-10" />

children.value:
You can create a component with the same name
in your app to override the default logo.
(The component must be registered as global)
Alternatively, you can display an image with:
The collapse layout focuses on a single sidebar with a list of menu links, ideal for smaller apps if you don't have enough content or pages to use a more complex layout like the sidebar layout.
The collapse layout can be folded into an icon sidebar. The collapse layout can have single menu links or submenu links. Clicking on a submenu link will revert the sidebar to its uncollapsed state
The toolbar is displayed at the top of the main content area. It can be used to display the current page title and a set of quick actions.
When scrolling down, the circular menu is displayed at the top right of the screen. It can be used to display a set of quick actions.
First you need to enable the collapse layout layer in the
Then you can configure the collapse layout in the
You don't need to specify all the properties, only the ones you want to override.
to the toolbar or the circular menu, you have to create global components, and add them to the
You can add a header or/and a footer to the navigation sidebar. You can use a global component or a local component.

The topnav layout focuses on a single topnavbar with a list of single links, ideal for smaller apps if you don't have enough content or pages to use a more complex layout like the sidebar or the collapse layout.
The top navigation layout provides a navbar header slot that we used to add a workspace selection dropdown. You can replace it with any component of your own.
When scrolling down, the circular menu is displayed at the bottom right of the screen. It can be used to display a set of quick actions.

Then you can configure the topnav layout in the
You don't need to specify all the properties, only the ones you want to override.
to the toolbar or the circular menu, you have to create global components, and add them to the

Tailwind CSS is a popular utility-first CSS framework that allows developers to quickly build modern and responsive user interfaces. The framework provides a large set of pre-defined utility classes that can be easily applied to HTML elements, helping to create visually appealing designs without having to write custom CSS code.
As example, the following HTML markup will create a link with a primary text color

props.code: A link with a primary text color

children.value: A link with a primary text color

For those familiar with preprocessors like SCSS, Tailwind CSS provides an organized and easy-to-learn approach to styling web applications. While SCSS allows us to write custom CSS code using variables, functions, and mixins, Tailwind CSS follows a utility-first approach where pre-defined CSS classes are used directly in HTML markup.

While the framework provides a large set of utility classes, it is essential to combine them with components in order to create a consistent user interface without writing repetitive code. By using Tailwind CSS with components, we can achieve a clean, efficient, and scalable design system.
which extends the default Tailwind CSS configuration without overriding it. This approach allows you to use the default Tailwind CSS configuration and Shuriken UI preset at the same time.
This includes a set of pre-defined utilities reusable in components like

Instead of hardcoding the default Tailwind CSS colors, Shuriken UI uses a set of colors that are more suitable for web applications. You can still use the default Tailwind CSS colors if you want to. Continue to
More fonts are added to the default Tailwind CSS configuration so you can fine tune your typography. Continue to
In addition to tailwind plugin and shuriken ui preset, Tairo adds some plugins which you can find in
plugin that exposes Tailwind CSS colors in native css variables.
Explore Shuriken UI predefined components on github.com
Tairo has full typescript support for tailwind, so you can create a
file to customize your Tailwind CSS configuration in your main app layer. You can customize fonts, spacing, radius, shadows, colors and more.
View the default Tailwind CSS configuration on github.com
View how content property is created on tailwindcss.nuxtjs.org
To make your application stand out, Tairo uses
custom color shades to allow you to easily customize the look and feel of your dashboard. By default, we use predefined colors from Tailwind CSS but you can easily change them by editing the

Open the Tairo theme customizer by clicking on the droplet icon in the sidebar. You can dynamically change the layout between the two available (more in future updates). You can change the primary color using one of the presets but also the background color, by selecting one of the available shades. The customizer is a useful tool that let's you see your brand color in action.
View default Tailwind CSS colors on tailwindcss.com
Generate shades for your custom colors with tailwindshades.com
Generate P-3 shades for your colors with tints.dev
color is the main color to establish brand recognition and familiarity of your application.

color is used to create a contrast between the primary color, text and the background color. To make your app look good in dark mode, you should use a color that fit well with the primary color: example, if your primary color is red, you should use a warm gray color for the muted color.
color is the secondary color used to highlight important information.
color is the color shade used to highlight actions that have been completed successfully.
color is the color shade used to raise attention to potentially dangerous actions or when something has gone wrong.
color is the color shade used to highlight actions that need to be taken.
fonts to allow you to create more unique designs. By default, we use predefined system fonts from Tailwind CSS but you can easily change them by editing the
As an example, this demo uses a custom set of fonts:

Defining a font in tailwind does not load the font for you. You need to load the font by yourself.
You can load fonts using
packages, you can browse the list of available fonts on
, then install the package using pnpm:

props.code: pnpm --filter tairo-quickstarter add --dev @fontsource-variable/open-sans

children.value: flag is used to install the package only in the
Then import the font in your
Shuriken UI register a set of Tailwind plugin that contains components. Each of them can be customized using the
This is an example to disable the default
Here is another example to increase errors font size and weight of

contents.title: Panels
contents.description: Tairo panels allow to display additional data and details in animated left or right drawers.

children.value: In order to use panels, you need to create a component in
folder to make them available in your app.

props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
// You can add props to the component
const props = withDefaults(
  defineProps<{
    color?: 'default' | 'primary' | 'secondary'
    projects?: any[]
  }>(),
  {
    color: 'default',
    projects: () => [],
  },
)

// Eiter define events
const emits = defineEmits<{
  (event: 'save', info: any): void
}>()

// And use panels utils
const { close } = usePanels()
</script>

<template>
  <BaseButtons>
    <BaseButton @click="() => emits('save', { selected: props.projects[0] })">Save</BaseButton>
    <BaseButton @click="() => close()">Cancel</BaseButton>
  </BaseButtons>
</template>

children.value:
<script setup lang="ts">
// You can add props to the component
const props = withDefaults(
  defineProps<{
    color?: 'default' | 'primary' | 'secondary'
    projects?: any[]
  }>(),
  {
    color: 'default',
    projects: () => [],
  },
)

// Eiter define events
const emits = defineEmits<{
  (event: 'save', info: any): void
}>()

// And use panels utils
const { close } = usePanels()
</script>

<template>
  <BaseButtons>
    <BaseButton @click="() => emits('save', { selected: props.projects[0] })">Save</BaseButton>
    <BaseButton @click="() => close()">Cancel</BaseButton>
  </BaseButtons>
</template>

Then you need to
register the panel in your
Once you have registered the panel, you can open it using the

props.code:
<script setup lang="ts">
const { open, close } = usePanels()

function onSomeEvent() {
  // close all panels first
  close()

  // open a panel by name
  open('panel-name', {
    // panel component props
    color: 'secondary',
    projects: [
      { name: 'Project 1' },
      { name: 'Project 2' },
      { name: 'Project 3' },
      { name: 'Project 4' },
    ],
    // panel component events, should be prefixed with `on`
    onSave (info) {
      console.log(info)
      // logs { selected: { name: 'Project 1' }
    }
  })
}
</script>

children.value:
<script setup lang="ts">
const { open, close } = usePanels()

function onSomeEvent() {
  // close all panels first
  close()

  // open a panel by name
  open('panel-name', {
    // panel component props
    color: 'secondary',
    projects: [
      { name: 'Project 1' },
      { name: 'Project 2' },
      { name: 'Project 3' },
      { name: 'Project 4' },
    ],
    // panel component events, should be prefixed with `on`
    onSave (info) {
      console.log(info)
      // logs { selected: { name: 'Project 1' }
    }
  })
}
</script>

contents.title: Form validation
contents.description: Form validation is a way to check if the data entered by the user is valid. Tairo provides a simple way to validate forms using the `veevalidate` and `zod` libraries.

children.value: Form validation is a way to check if the data entered by the user is valid. Tairo provides a simple way to validate forms using the

Vee-validate provides vue components and composable to control fields and form whereas zod is a library to define schemas. In the example below, we show how both work with Tairo with a simple user profile form.
Note that you can totally remove those dependencies, Tairo and Shuriken components won't be affected.

Pnpm workspace is a powerful tool for managing multiple packages in a single repository. It can help you keep your dependencies in sync and reduce the time and disk space required for package installation. If you're working on a project that uses pnpm workspace, you can take advantage of this feature to manage your packages more efficiently.

Another feature of pnpm workspace is hoisting, which allows you to install dependencies at the root level instead of in each workspace. This can further reduce the disk space and installation time required for your packages.

Overall, pnpm workspace can be a powerful tool for managing multiple packages in a single repository. It can help you keep your dependencies in sync and reduce the time and disk space required for package installation. If you're new to pnpm workspace, it's worth taking the time to learn how to use it effectively.
Read more about workspace on pnpm.io
file to define the workspace structure. This file is located at the root of the project and contains a list of workspace directories.

props.code:
packages:
  - .app
  - .demo
  - layers/*

children.value: All folders listed in this file that contains a
file will be considered in the workspace. You can use wildcards to automatically include all folders that match a pattern, like with the
As an example, you could create a new folder for your backend and add it to the workspace:

props.code:
packages:
  - .app
  - .backend # replace unused .demo with .backend
  - layers/*

props.title: Install dependencies in the right place

children.value: By default, if you don't specify a package filter, pnpm will install dependencies in the root
file. This is not what we want when using pnpm workspace.
Instead we want to install it in the package that contains our layer. For example, if we want to install a dependency in the
layer, we should use the following command:

props.code: pnpm --filter tairo-quickstarter install --dev my-dependency

children.value: This will find packages in the workspace that has the name
and install the dependency in it (here it matches
from the previous example instead of
to install the dependency in the
in the layer directory. This will install dependencies in the layer directory instead of the root directory.

props.code:
cd .app
pnpm install --dev my-dependency

children.value: If you want to update a dependency in a workspace, you should use the
flag in order to update the dependency in all layers.

props.code: pnpm update --recursive --latest --interactive

children.value: Select dependencies you want to update and press enter.
Once the update is done, you need to remove all
Note that it may be possible that we have patched some dependencies, updating them may or may not include our fixes. If you encounter any issue, please report it on our
directory in the workspace and delete them:

props.code: find . -maxdepth 4 -name node_modules -type d -prune -exec rm -rf {} \;

children.value: Before you can deploy your application, you need to know how to build it. This guide will show you how to build your application.

Nuxt have two different ways to build your application, for static hosting or server-rendered application. Each one has its own advantages and disadvantages, so it's important to know which one is best for your use case.
Faster load times: Static sites are pre-built and served as-is, which means they can be delivered to the user more quickly than server-rendered sites.
Lower hosting costs: Static sites can be hosted on services like GitHub Pages or Netlify for free or at a low cost, whereas server-rendered sites require more powerful hosting solutions.
Limited interactivity: Static sites can't provide the same level of interactivity as server-rendered sites because they don't have a server-side component.
Harder to update: Static sites require a rebuild and redeploy every time you make a change, which can be time-consuming and error-prone.
Limited functionality: Static sites can't perform complex server-side operations like processing payments or sending emails without the use of third-party services.
Limited dynamic content: Static sites can't easily display dynamic content like user-specific data or real-time updates without the use of client-side JavaScript.
command to generate a static site from your application. This command will create a
directory that contains all of the files needed to serve your application statically.

props.code: npx nuxi generate .app

children.value: after the command to specify the layer you want to build.
Before deploying, you can ensure that the generated files are correct by using the

props.code: npx serve .app/.output/public

children.value: More interactivity: Server-rendered sites can provide a higher level of interactivity because they have a server-side component that can handle user input and perform complex operations.
Easier to update: Server-rendered sites can be updated more easily because changes can be made on the server and don't require a rebuild and redeploy.
More functionality: Server-rendered sites can perform complex server-side operations like processing payments or sending emails without the use of third-party services.
More dynamic content: Server-rendered sites can easily display dynamic content like user-specific data or real-time updates.
Slower load times: Server-rendered sites require more processing on the server before they can be delivered to the user, which can result in slower load times.
Higher hosting costs: Server-rendered sites require more powerful hosting solutions, which can be more expensive than static hosting.
command to generate a static site from your application. This command will create a
directory that contains all of the files needed to serve your application with a server.

Nuxt build is performed through Nitro which can output your application for different platforms. By default, it will output a Node.js application, but it comes with many presets like for Bun, Deno, Vercel, Cloudflare, etc.

props.code: NITRO_PRESET=node-cluster npx nuxi build .app

children.value: after the command to specify the layer you want to build.
Before deploying, you can ensure that the application runs correctly by using:

props.code: node .app/.output/server/index.mjs

children.value: You can also use Docker to build and run your application. This is useful if you want to deploy your application on containers like Kubernetes or Docker Swarm.

props.code:
# Build stage
FROM bitnami/node:18 AS build
WORKDIR /app

# Install pnpm with corepack
RUN corepack enable && corepack prepare pnpm@latest --activate

# Prepare pnpm dependencies using lockfile, patches and docker cache
COPY pnpm-lock.yaml .
COPY patches/ patches/
RUN --mount=type=cache,id=pnpm,target=/root/.local/share/pnpm/store pnpm fetch

# Install and build the app
COPY . .
RUN pnpm install
RUN pnpm build

# Production stage
FROM bitnami/node:18 AS prod
WORKDIR /app

# Create a non-root user
RUN groupadd -g 10001 nuxt && \
  useradd -u 10001 -g nuxt nuxt \
  && chown -R nuxt:nuxt /app

# Switch to the non-root user
USER nuxt:nuxt

# Set the environment to production
ENV NODE_ENV=production

# Copy the built app from the build stage
COPY --chown=nuxt:nuxt --from=build /app/.app/.output .output

# Expose the port
EXPOSE 3000

# Start the app
CMD ["node", ".output/server/index.mjs"]

children.value:
# Build stage
FROM bitnami/node:18 AS build
WORKDIR /app

# Install pnpm with corepack
RUN corepack enable && corepack prepare pnpm@latest --activate

# Prepare pnpm dependencies using lockfile, patches and docker cache
COPY pnpm-lock.yaml .
COPY patches/ patches/
RUN --mount=type=cache,id=pnpm,target=/root/.local/share/pnpm/store pnpm fetch

# Install and build the app
COPY . .
RUN pnpm install
RUN pnpm build

# Production stage
FROM bitnami/node:18 AS prod
WORKDIR /app

# Create a non-root user
RUN groupadd -g 10001 nuxt && \
  useradd -u 10001 -g nuxt nuxt \
  && chown -R nuxt:nuxt /app

# Switch to the non-root user
USER nuxt:nuxt

# Set the environment to production
ENV NODE_ENV=production

# Copy the built app from the build stage
COPY --chown=nuxt:nuxt --from=build /app/.app/.output .output

# Expose the port
EXPOSE 3000

# Start the app
CMD ["node", ".output/server/index.mjs"]

This Dockerfile uses a multi-stage build to separate the build and production stages. The build stage installs pnpm and builds the application, while the production stage copies the built application from the build stage and runs it, using a non-root user for security reasons. This allow to keep only the built application in the production image.
Then, build and run the Docker image:

props.code: docker build --tag my-frontend-app:1.0.0 .

children.value: Once the image is built, you can run it using:

props.code: docker run --rm --publish 3000:3000 my-frontend-app:1.0.0

children.value: Read about multi-stage build on docker.com
Deep dive in Typescript on basarat.gitbook.io
Nuxt is a framework that combines a set of tools and libraries to create applications. It's important to know what tools are used in order to understand how to solve potential issues.
It uses Vite as a development tool, and Rollup to build the production version of your app.
We highly encourage you to both read their troubleshooting guides, as they might be able to help you to solve your issue.
: contains common issues with the development server (ex: requests stalled, hot reloading, etc.)
: contains common issues with the production build (ex: memory issues, tree-shaking, etc.)
If you encounter issues that you can't solve, you can start the project in debug mode. This will enable the verbose mode of Nuxt, which will output more information in the console.

props.code:
# Enable Nuxt debug mode
DEBUG=1 pnpm dev # or pnpm build

children.value:
# Enable Nuxt debug mode
DEBUG=1 pnpm dev # or pnpm build
Vite also has a debug mode, which can be enabled by setting the

props.code:
# Enable Nuxt & Vite debug mode
DEBUG=vite:* pnpm dev # or pnpm build

children.value:
# Enable Nuxt & Vite debug mode
DEBUG=vite:* pnpm dev # or pnpm build
You can send those logs to us on our
When the documentation layer is enabled, or when building the full demo, you may need to increase the memory limit of Node.js. This is because the documentation layer uses
to generate the components documentation. When building the demo, Rollup will also

props.code:
# Increase the memory limit to 8GB
NODE_OPTIONS=--max-old-space-size=8192 pnpm demo:build

children.value:
# Increase the memory limit to 8GB
NODE_OPTIONS=--max-old-space-size=8192 pnpm demo:build
to debug your application. This is useful when you want to inspect the state of your application at a specific time.
Tairo has a pre-configured launch configuration for VS Code. You can use it by clicking on the "Run and Debug" button in the sidebar, and then selecting "fullstack: nuxt" in the dropdown.
Then you can define breakpoints in your code, and start the debugger. The debugger will stop at the breakpoints you defined, and you will be able to inspect the state of your application.
In addition to the breakpoints, you can also use the
keyword in your code to stop the execution of your application. This is useful when you want to inspect the state of your application at a specific time.
which provide a set of tools to inspect your application. This is useful when you want to inspect the state of your application at a specific time, inspect components, pages, etc.
First you need to install the

props.code: pnpm --filter tairo-quickstarter install --dev @nuxt/devtools

contents.description: A switch is a binary input that can be either on or off. It is used to toggle between two states. Check out the thin and the ball versions.

prop to set the sublabel text and modify the swicth layout.

contents.title: BaseTreeSelect
contents.description: Display data tree in collapsible items. Can be used to select node in tree.

children.value: The TreeSelect component is used to render a data treeview. It provides a simple way to select a node in a tree.

The TreeSelect can be used to display data from an async source. Take a look at the code example for more details about usage.

contents.title: Sliders
contents.description: Tairo ships with the powerful vueform slider component. Use it to render fancy sliders with or without tooltips and the ability to merge them.

prop. Check out the code example for more details about usage.
